case_data.name: Johnson v. Upchurch
case_data.plaintiff_description: inmates at Catalina Mountain Juvenile Institution
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On April 6, 1986, inmates at Catalina Mountain Juvenile Institution (now known as Catalina Mountain School) near Tucson, Arizona, filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Education for the Handicapped Act against the former and acting superintendents of Catalina Mountain Juvenile Institution; the acting superintendent of Catalina Mountain; the director of the Arizona Department of Corrections; and the director of Juvenile Services for the Arizona Department of Corrections. The suit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.

The plaintiffs, who were represented by the National Center for Youth Law and private counsel, filed a Sixth Amended Complaint on April 9, 1990, and asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging the defendants' treatment and policies violated the juveniles' constitutional rights. The plaintiffs sought to change confinement practices and to require adequate procedural protections prior to inflicting harsh and cruel punishments. They also sought to require medical care and adequate educational programs, and to evaluate juveniles for handicapping conditions in accordance with the Education for the Handicapped Act. Finally, the plaintiffs sought to change the defendants' interference with the juveniles' access to legal counsel and their restrictive visitation policies. In addition, certain plaintiffs asked certain defendants for damages.

The parties entered into a Consent Decree on May 6, 1993, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona. The court (Judge Richard M. Bilby) issued an injunction to last four years. It required the defendants to house juveniles in the least restrictive environment and instituted population limitations. It further required defendants to form an individual treatment plan for each inmate, and to provide medical, dental, and psychiatric care. It provided guidelines for educational assessments, progress monitoring, and work programs. Finally, it prohibited arbitrary punishments. The Consent Decree provided for monitoring through a committee, which would conduct inspections and issue written reports on the progress.

On April 15, 1996, the court (Judge Bilby) issued an order finding the Arizona Department of Juvenile Corrections out of compliance with the Consent Decree, in that the Department failed to adhere to the Decree's requirements limiting the population in juvenile facilities to designated levels and demanding the approval of the monitoring committee before increasing the total number of beds. The court ordered the Department to resolve this matter within 30 days. Compliance reports continued to be filed with the court and the docket continues through June 2000.

documents.title: Corrected Sixth Amended Complaint
documents.text:
Johnson v. Upchurch
Grace Mcllvain  " " JI-AZ-002-001
1
MILLER & PITT
111 South Church  Avenue
2
Tucson, Arizona  85701-1680
602-792-3836
3
David  Lambert
4
NATIONAL CENTER FOR YOUTH LAW
114 Sansome Street, Suite 900
5 San Francisco, California  94104-3820
415-543-3307
6
Attorneys for Plaintiffs
7
8 IN THE UNITED STATES  DISTRICT  COURT
9 FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA
10
11 MATTHEW  DAVEY JOHNSON; S.G., a minor,)
by and through his mother and next  )
12 friend, A.G.; P.M., a minor, by and  )
through his mother and next  friend,  )
13 V.J.; D.F., a minor, by and through  )
his mother and next  friend S.F.;  )
14 M.G., a minor, by and through  )
his  father and next friend D.G.;  )
15 O.S., a minor, by and through  ) NO.  CIV-86-195-TUC-RMB
his  father and next  friend A.S.;  )
16 D.A.,  a minor, by and through  ) C O R R E C T ED
his  father and next  friend, J.A.;  )
17 and B.L., a minor, by and  ) SIXTH  AMENDED  COMPLAINT
through his father and next  )
18 friend, D.L., on behalf of themselves)
and all others similarly  situated,
19
Plaintiffs,
20
vs.
21
JAMES  R. UPCHURCH,  in his
personal  capacity; GENE MOORE,
22
in his official capacity as Acting
Superintendent of Catalina  Mountain
23
Juvenile  Institution; SAMUEL LEWIS,
in his official capacity as Director
24
of the Arizona  Department of
Corrections; and CAROL MOORE HURTT,
25
in her official  capacity as Director
of Juvenile  Services for the Arizona
26
Department of Corrections,
27
Defendants.
28

r
INTRODUCTION
1.  This is a civil rights class action which  concerns
2
policies, practices, and conditions  of confinement at the  Catalina
3
Mountain Juvenile Institution  (CMJI) near Tucson, Arizona.
4
Plaintiffs are juveniles who are or who have been confined  at CMJI
5
and who have been subjected by defendants, acting under color of
6
state law, to cruel, unconscionable, and illegal conditions  of
7
confinement.
8
2.  Plaintiff MATTHEW DAVEY JOHNSON  seeks damages  from
9
Defendant JAMES UPCHURCH who  is sued  in his personal  capacity.
10
Plaintiff M.G. seeks damages  from defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and
11
THOMAS KORFF who are sued in their personal  capacities.
12
3.  Plaintiffs MATTHEW DAVEY JOHNSON and plaintiffs  S.G.,
13
R.M.,  D.F., M.G., O.S., D.A.,  and B.L. seek  declaratory,
14
injunctive, and other equitable relief on behalf of themselves  and
15
all other juveniles similarly situated who are, or who will  be
16
confined at CMJI and thereby  subjected to the cruel,
17
unconscionable, and  illegal practices of defendants.
18
JURISDICTION
19
4.  This Court has jurisdiction of this action under  28
20
U.S.C. Section 1343(3) and  (4); 28 U.S.C. Section 1331(a);  28
21
U.S.C. Sections 2201 and 2202; 20 U.S.C. Section 1401 et seq., and
22
the regulations promulgated thereunder; and Federal Rules of  Civil
23
Procedure 57 and 65.  Plaintiffs' claims for relief are  authorized
24
by 42 U.S.C. Section 1983 which provides for redress of
25
deprivations under color of state law or rights guaranteed by the
26
Constitution and laws of the United  States.
27
5.  This Court has jurisdiction of plaintiffs' state  law
28

f  f
claims under the doctrine of pendent jurisdiction, which permits
federal courts to determine state law claims which form separate
but parallel grounds for relief also sought in substantial  claims
based on federal law.
4
PLAINTIFFS
6.  Plaintiffs who bring this action by and through a
6
parent as their next friend have not reached their  eighteenth
. birthday.  The plaintiffs and their next friends are actual
persons and, except for plaintiff JOHNSON, sue under  fictitious
names because they fear humiliation and embarrassment  if their
10
true identities are made public.
11
7.  At the time of filing of the Fourth Amended Complaint,
12
plaintiff MATTHEW DAVEY JOHNSON was 18 years of age; a citizen of
13
the United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He was
14
confined at CMJI from October, 1985, until December, 1986.
15
Plaintiff JOHNSON initiated this action in April, 1986, by and
16
through his father as next friend but has since reached his
17
eighteenth birthday and sues in this Amended Complaint on his own
18
behalf.
19
8.  Plaintiff s.G. is 14 years of age; a citizen of the
20
United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
21
currently confined in CMJI and has been so confined since
22
November, 1986.  He brings this action by and through A.G., his
23
mother, as next friend.
24
9.  Plaintiff P.M. is 17 years of age; a citizen of the
25
United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
26
currently confined in CMJI and has been so confined since August,
27
1986.  He brings this action by and through V.J., his mother, as
28

f  f
next friend.
10.  Plaintiff D.F. is 17 years of age; a citizen of the
2  United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
currently confined in CMJI and has been so confined since
November, 1986.  He brings this action by and through S.F., his
,  mother, as next friend,
o
  11.  Plaintiff M.G., is a resident of the United States and
7
a citizen of the State of Arizona. At the time that the Fourth
8
9 Amended Complaint was filed, M.G. was 15 years old and he brought
10 that action by and through D.G., his father and next friend. M.G.
11 reached his eighteenth birthday on January 12, 1990 and sues in
this Amended Complaint on his own behalf.
12
12.  Plaintiff O.S. is 17 years of age; a citizen of the
13
United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
14
currently confined in CMJI and has been so confined since July,
15
1986.  He brings this action by and through A.S., his father, as
16
next friend.
17
13.  Plaintiff D.A. is 17 years of age; a citizen of the
18
United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
19
currently confined in CMJI and has been so confined since July,
20
1986.  He brings this action by and through J.A., his father, as
21
next friend.
22
14.  Plaintiff B.L. is 14 years of age; a citizen of the
23
United States; and a resident of the State of Arizona.  He is
24
currently confined at CMJI and has been so confined since April,
25
1986.  He brings this action by and through D.L., his father, as
26
next friend.
27
28

f  f
DEFENDANTS
โ  15.  Defendant JAMES UPCHURCH was the Superintendent of
CMJI from January, 198 6, to November, 198 6.  As such, he was
responsible for the day to day administration and management of
4
CMJI, for formulating, implementing, and approving policies and
decisions affecting juveniles confined at CMJI, and for training,
6
directing, and supervising persons at CMJI responsible for the
care and custody of plaintiffs, including volunteer counselors.
8
He is sued in his personal capacity.
16.  Defendant THOMAS KORFF has been Superintendent of CMJI
10
continuously since May, 1987. In that capacity he is responsible
11
for the day to day administration and management of CMJI, for
12
formulating, implementing, and approving policies and decisions
13
affecting juveniles confined at CMJI, and for training, directing,
14
and supervising persons at CMJI responsible for the care and
15
custody of plaintiffs, including volunteer counselors. He is sued
16
in his personal capacity.
17
17.  Defendant SAMUEL LEWIS is the Director of the Arizona
18
Department of Corrections.  As such, pursuant to Arizona Revised
19
Statutes 42-1603, he is responsible for maintaining and
20
administering CMJI for the treatment and rehabilitation of youth
21
offenders, and for implementing Arizona Department of Corrections
22
regulations, policies, and rules affecting juveniles confined at
23
CMJI.  During all times relevant to this complaint, he has been
24
responsible for supervising defendants UPCHURCH, MOORE and KORFF.
25
He is sued in his official capacity.
96
18.  Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT has been Assistant
27
Director for Juvenile and Community Services in the Arizona
28

Department of Corrections continuously since April, 1985. In that
capacity she is responsible for the general supervision and
management of juvenile institutions in Arizona, including CMJI,
and for implementing Arizona Department of Corrections
4
regulations, rules, and policies affecting juveniles confined at
CMJI. Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT was the immediate supervisor of
6
Defendant JAMES UPCHURCH from April, 1985 to November, 1986, and
has been the immediate supervisor of Defendant THOMAS KORFF since
8
May, 1987. She is sued in her personal capacity.
9
19.  Defendant C. DIANE BISHOP, is the Superintendent of
10
Public Instruction and Director of the Arizona Department of
11
Education.  She also is the Executive Officer of the Arizona State
12
Board of Education.  Under Arizona law, she is primarily
13
responsible for state supervision and enforcement of all laws,
14
rules and regulations concerning elementary and secondary
15
education in Arizona and, pursuant to federal and state laws and
16
regulations, she is primarily responsible for the provision of
17
special education and related services to all eligible
18
''handicapped children," as that term is defined in the Education
19
for all Handicapped Children Act and Arizona Revised Statutes 15-
20
761, including such children confined at CMJI.  She is sued in her
21
official capacity.
22
20.  Defendant, the ARIZONA BOARD OF EDUCATION, is the
23
statutorily created entity responsible for setting and enforcing
24
educational policy in the State.  It has the authority to and has
25
adopted rules and regulations regarding elementary and secondary
26
education, including the provision of special education services
27
to "educationally handicapped" children as that term is defined in
28

f  f
,  the Education for all Handicapped Children Act and Arizona Revised
โ  Statutes 15-761, including such children confined at CMJI.
โ  21.  In doing the acts described herein, each of the
defendants has acted under color of state law and by virtue of the
authority vested in each of them as employees of the State of
Arizona.
6
CLASS ACTION
22.  Plaintiffs bring this action on their own behalf and
8
on behalf of all others similarly situated pursuant to Rule 23(a)
9
and  (b)2 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  tHe class
10
consists of all juveniles who are now or who in the future will be
11
confined at CMJI.
12
23.  The.members of the class are so numerous that joinder
13
of all members is impracticable.  On information and belief, there
14
are approximately 175 juveniles presently confined at CMJI and
15
other juveniles are brought into the institution with regularity.
16
In addition, there are questions of law and fact common to the
17
members of the plaintiff class regarding practices of the
18
defendants, and the claims of the named plaintiffs are typical of
19
the claims of the members of the plaintiff class.  The named
20
plaintiffs and plaintiffs' counsel will fairly and adequately
21
protect the interests of the members of the class.f
22
24.  By their policies, the defendants have acted and
23
continue to act on grounds and in a manner generally applicable to
24
the class, thereby making appropriate final injunctive relief or
25
corresponding declaratory relief with respect to the class as a
26
whole.
27
25.  The injuries suffered by the named plaintiffs and the
28

members of the plaintiff class as a result of the policies and
practices of defendants are capable of repetition, yet may  evade
review, thereby making class relief  appropriate.
FACTUAL  ALLEGATIONS
4
A.  FACTS IN SUPPORT OF CLAIMS FOR DECLARATORY. INJUNCTIVE. AND
5  OTHER EQUITABLE RELIEF
6  I.  DISCIPLINARY  PRACTICES
'  A.  Solitary  Confinement
26.  Defendants maintain a punishment cottage at CMJI known
ยฐ  as Yucca Cottage which contains 16 cells.  These cells are
10  approximately  9' x 9' and are of concrete block construction  with
11  bare cement floors and heavy barred doors.  Except in two of the
12  cells which contain uncovered  institutional-style  toilets and
13  sinks, there are no furnishings  in the cells except a heavy metal
14  bed  frame stationed on metal  legs.
15  27.  Defendants have failed to maintain these cells in a
16  safe condition.  The cells are inadequately heated  in winter and
17  inadequately cooled in summer; they are inadequately  lighted, and
18  they are unclean and  unsanitary.
19  28.  Defendants have confined plaintiffs  in these cells  for
2Q  periods ranging from several hours to weeks or even months.  For
example, defendants confined plaintiff JOHNSON  in Yucca  Cottage
22  for over 50 consecutive days.  Defendants confined plaintiff  D.A.
23  in Yucca Cottage on at least seven occasions  for periods as long
as thirteen days.  Defendants confined plaintiff O.S. in Yucca
Cottage on at least 3 0 occasions for periods as long as  seven
days.  Defendants have confined  each of the plaintiffs  in Yucca
27  Cottage.
29.  Defendants have confined plaintiffs  in cells in Yucca
8

(  f
Cottage twenty-four hours a day except  for brief periods to use
the bathroom  or shower or for periods  of forced  exercise.
Defendants permit plaintiffs to shower only every  other day and to
3
leave their cells to exercise only after they have been  in
4
solitary  confinement  for five consecutive  days.  On  occasion,
5
defendants have denied plaintiffs  confined  in Yucca  Cottage
6
permission to leave their cells to go to the bathroom  and, as a
7
result, plaintiffs have urinated  or defecated  on the floor  of
8
their  cells.
9
30.  Defendants have failed to provide  adequate  clothing
10
for plaintiffs  in Yucca Cottage cells.  Before being placed  in
11
these cells, defendants strip-search plaintiffs  and give them  only
12
a jumpsuit to wear.  On occasion, defendants have  denied
13
plaintiffs  jumpsuits and have confined  plaintiffs  in Yucca  Cottage
14
cells with no clothing but underwear.  For example,  defendants
15
confined  plaintiff  D.A.  in a cell  in Yucca  Cottage overnight  with
16
no clothing but underwear.  Defendants do not permit plaintiffs  to
17
wear  shoes while confined  in Yucca Cottage and defendants  often do
18
not permit plaintiffs to wear  socks.
19
31.  Defendants have failed to provide  adequate bedding  to
20
plaintiffs while  in Yucca Cottage cells.  Defendants  give
21
plaintiffs  a mattress and one small blanket  each night and  then
22
remove the mattress  and blanket  from the cell each morning.  On
23
occasion, defendants withhold mattresses  and blankets at night  as
24
additional  punishment.
25
32.  Defendants have failed to take sufficient  precautions
26
in the event of fire to adequately  protect plaintiffs  in  Yucca
27
Cottage  cells.  For example, defendants  lock cells  in  Yucca
28

r
Cottage individually with padlocks and have failed to provide an
adequate plan for evacuation in the event of fire.
33.  Defendants have confined depressed, agitated and
emotionally disturbed children in solitary confinement in Yucca
4
Cottage and defendants have taken inadequate measures to protect
them from self-injury.  As a result plaintiffs have cut, hanged
6
and otherwise injured themselves.
34.  Defendants have failed to provide adequate psychiatric
8
and psychological counseling and other mental health services to
plaintiffs held in solitary confinement in Yucca Cottage,
10
including those plaintiffs who have injured or attempted to injure
11
themselves.  As a result, plaintiffs have suffered serious
12
psychological stress, including the effects of sensory
13
deprivation, while in Yucca Cottage.
14
35.  Defendants have failed to provide educational programs
15
for plaintiffs in Yucca Cottage and they have failed to provide
16
appropriate reading materials.  In addition, defendants have
17
prevented plaintiffs from participating in educational programs
18
which they have tried to pursue on their own initiative.  For
19
example, defendants intentionally and deliberately denied
20
plaintiff JOHNSON the opportunity to take the Graduate Equivalency
21
Degree Examination  (GED) because he was in Yucca Cottage.
22
36.  Defendants have failed to provide rehabilitative
23
treatment or counseling programs for plaintiffs in Yucca Cottage.
24
37.  Plaintiffs have suffered and continue to suffer
25
serious emotional and physical injury as a result of defendants'
26
practices regarding confinement in Yucca Cottage.
27
28
10

f  c
.  B.  Punitive Segregation
38.  Defendants confine plaintiffs in Yucca Cottage cells
for indefinite periods of time in a program known as "motivational
hold" or "structured management."  Defendants permit plaintiffs in
4
punitive segregation to leave Yucca Cottage only to perform hard
labor or to attend school.  Defendants sometimes deny plaintiffs
6
in punitive segregation the opportunity to attend school or to
otherwise participate in any educational program.
8
39.  Defendants permit plaintiffs in punitive segregation
to visit only with their parents and only for one-half hour on
10
Saturdays and one-half hour on Sundays.  Defendants deny
11
plaintiffs in punitive segregation the opportunity to communicate
12
by telephone with family members.
13
40.  Defendants fail to provide plaintiffs in punitive
14
segregation with appropriate counseling, recreation, and other
15
rehabilitative treatment.
16
C.  Handcuffing and Shackling
17
41.  Defendants use metal, police-style handcuffs and leg
18
shackles to punish plaintiffs for violations of institutional
19
rules.  For example, defendants placed plaintiff D.A. in handcuffs
20
and leg shackles for refusing to shovel dirt and required him to
21
stand in the sun for two hours.
22
42.  Defendants also use metal handcuffs to restrain
23
plaintiffs whenever they are taken to Yucca Cottage or moved from
24
Yucca Cottage.  Defendants have restrained all of the plaintiffs
25
in metal handcuffs before* taking them to Yucca Cottage even though
26
they offered no resistance and posed no threat to the security of
27
the institution.
28
11

43.  Defendants have also used handcuffs to punish
plaintiffs for violations of institutional  rules by restraining
their arms and legs to the corners of bed frames in what is known
3
as "four-pointing."  For example, defendants  "four-pointed"
4
plaintiff M.G. and left him on a metal bed frame for several  hours
5
because he was involved in a fight.
6
44.  Plaintiffs have suffered and continue to. suffer
7
serious physical and emotional  injury as a result of defendants'
8
use of handcuffs and shackles.
9
D.  Disciplinary Due Process
10
45.  Defendants  subject plaintiffs to cruel,  excessive,
11
harsh, and brutal punishments for violations of petty, vague, and
12
ambiguous  institutional  rules.  For example, defendants  punish
13
plaintiffs by placing them in handcuffs and leg shackles, by
14
locking them in solitary confinement  cells, by placing them in
15
punitive  segregation, and by extending  their period of confinement
16
in the institution for such rule violations as smoking,  swearing,
17
"staff disrespect," "excessive horseplay," and "rumor of AWOL."
18
46.  Defendants have failed to adequately  train and
19
supervise  institutional  staff and have permitted  institutional
20
staff to impose cruel and harsh punishments  in an arbitrary and
21
capricious manner.  For example, defendants have  authorized
22
institutional  staff, as well as volunteer  "counselors" who are not
23
employees of the institution, to punish plaintiffs by having  them
24
placed in handcuffs, shackles, solitary confinement, and punitive
25
segregation.
26
47.  Prior to the imposition of such harsh and brutal
27
punishments, defendants fail to provide plaintiffs with written
28
12

f  (
notice of any alleged rule infractions and an opportunity to
โ  adequately defend.  Defendants fail to provide hearings which are
adequate to determine whether a rule violation has occurred,
whether the child charged committed the violation, and to
determine the most appropriate disciplinary sanction for a child
5
who has violated an institutional rule.
6
48.  Defendants have failed to establish any effective
grievance or appeal process for plaintiffs who have been subjected
8
to arbitrary, cruel, excessive, and illegal punishments.
II.  MEDICAL CARE
10
49.  Defendants have failed to adequately screen and
11
evaluate plaintiffs prior to or at the time of placement in CMJI
12
to determine their medical, dental, and mental health needs.
13
50.  Defendants have failed to provide adequate and
14
appropriate medical, counseling and mental health services to
15
plaintiffs who have cut, hanged or otherwise injured themselves.
16
51.  Defendants have failed to design and implement an
17
adequate and appropriate treatment procedure for plaintiffs who
18
are injured or ill or to provide an appropriate facility to
19
provide for their needs.  As a result, plaintiffs who are injured
20
or ill are confined in Yucca Cottage.
21
52.  Defendants have failed to protect the plaintiffs and
22
members of their class from the excessive or inappropriate use of
23
psychotropic and anti-depressant drugs.  Defendants administer
24
such drugs to plaintiffs and members of their class for purposes
25
of punishment and control.
26
III.  EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING
27
53.  Defendants are recipients of federal funds within the
28
13

r
1  meaning of the Education for All Handicapped Children Act, 20
โ  U.S.C. Section 1401, et seq.
โ  54.  Defendants have failed to adequately evaluate
plaintiffs to determine whether they have special education needs
_  and how such special needs can be met.  Defendants also have
,  failed to develop appropriate individualized education plans for
6
  plaintiffs who require special education.  For example, plaintiff
7
P.M. has a stuttering problem and plaintiff M.G. has speech and
o
language disorders and has been determined to be seriously
emotionally disturbed.  Despite knowledge of the handicapping
conditions, defendants have failed to provide plaintiffs with an
11
educational program which addresses these special needs.
12
55.  Defendants have failed to hire, adequately train and
13
supervise sufficient numbers of qualified personnel to meet the
14
special education and releited needs of juveniles confined at CMJI.
15
For example, there currently are no special education classes at
16
CMJI because the special education teacher position is vacant.
17
This vacancy has existed since at least January 1988.  As a
18
result, juveniles at CMJI who are eligible for and/or in need of
19
special education services are not assigned to special education
20
classes or otherwise provided special education or related
21
services.
22
57.  Contrary to the mandates of 20 U.S.C. Section 1415
23
(b)(1)(B), and regulations promulgated thereunder, specifically 34
24
C.F.R. 300.514, defendants have failed to recruit, tram or assign
25
"surrogate parents" to juveniles confined at CMJI who are eligible
26
for and/or in need of special education services.
27
58.  Defendants C. DIANE BISHOP, the ARIZONA BOARD OF
28
14

EDUCATION, CAROL MOORE, and SAM LEWIS have failed to adequately
monitor CMJI to insure that all eligible handicapped juveniles
confined at the institution are identified, evaluated, and
provided appropriate and necessary special education and related
4
services in a manner that complies with the requirements of
federal and state statutes and regulations.
59.  Defendants have failed to provide an educational
program for plaintiffs which complies with the requirements of
8
Arizona law.
9
IV.  REHABILITATIVE  CARE  AND  TREATMENT
10 60.  Defendants have failed to provide rehabilitative
11 services and treatment to plaintiffs in the least restrictive
12 environment appropriate to their needs.
13 V.  INAPPROPRIATE PLACEMENT, EVALUATION, AND CLASSIFICATION
14 61.  Defendants have failed to design and implement an
15 appropriate classification system for plaintiffs.  As a result,
16 plaintiffs are arbitrarily confined in the institution, and
17 assigned to cottages within the institution, without regard to
18 their treatment needs.
62.  Defendants have failed to adequately evaluate
19
plaintiffs as to their educational, vocational, psychological, and
20
treatment needs.
21
63.  Defendants have failed to prepare adequate individual
22
treatment plans for plaintiffs.
23
64.  Defendants have failed to evaluate plaintiffs in order
24
to determine whether CMJI is the least restrictive placement
25
appropriate to their needs.  For example, plaintiff D.F. is
26
incarcerated at CMJI for running away from a group home and
27
28
15

f  f
plaintiff P.M.  is incarcerated at CMJI for a probation violation
โ  involving  loitering.  Plaintiff B.L. is incarcerated  at CMJI while
he is awaiting a hearing on a charge of joy riding.
65.  Defendants have failed to develop and implement  less
,.  secure, community-based alternative placements for plaintiffs and
members of their class who are inappropriately confined at CMJI.
VI.  VISITATION. CORRESPONDENCE, AND ACCESS TO  COUNSEL
66.  Defendants have prohibited and otherwise  restricted
8
contact between plaintiffs and members of their families.  For
example, defendants permit plaintiffs in solitary confinement and
10
punitive segregation to visit only with their parents and only for
11
one-half hour on Saturday, and one-half hour on Sunday.
12
Defendants also restrict and prohibit plaintiffs  from talking with
13
parents and other family members by telephone.  For example,
14
defendants denied plaintiff JOHNSON the opportunity to visit with
15
his father or to receive telephone calls from his father for three
16
months.
17
67.  Defendants have unlawfully confiscated, read, and
18
withheld plaintiffs' legal documents and communications with their
19
attorneys.  For example, defendants searched plaintiff  JOHNSON'S
20
cell and confiscated, read, and withheld his legal papers and
21
correspondence despite his objections and repeated requests that
22
they be returned.
23
VII  PAROLE REVOCATION
24
68.  Defendants have knowingly and deliberately  failed to
25
establish parole revocation procedures which are adequate to
26
protect the rights of plaintiffs and the class they represent.
27
69.  Defendants have subjected plaintiffs to parole
28
16

f
revocation procedures which violate their rights guaranteed by the
โ  United States Constitution and the Arizona Constitution.
B.  FACTS IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFF MATTHEW DAVEY JOHNSON'S
CLAIMS FOR DAMAGES AGAINST DEFENDANT UPCHURCH
4
70.  As a direct and proximate result of the failure of
defendant UPCHURCH to properly train and supervise volunteer
6
counselors at CMJI, on August 4, 1986, plaintiff JOHNSON was
summarily handcuffed and confined in a solitary confinement cell
6
in Yucca Cottage.  This cell was approximately 9' x 9' and of
concrete block construction with a bare cement floor and a heavy
10
barred door.  A heavy metal bed frame stationed on metal legs and
11
an uncovered, institutional-style toilet and sink were the only
12
furnishings in the cell.  The cell was not maintained at an
13
appropriate, and comfortable temperature, it was not adequately
14
lighted, and it was not clean.
15
71.  As a direct and proximate result of the failure of
16
defendant UPCHURCH to establish an adequate hearing procedure and
17
other safeguards, plaintiff JOHNSON was denied the opportunity to
18
present testimony of witnesses who had first-hand knowledge of
19
events which led to his solitary confinement and to otherwise
20
present an adequate defense.  On August 5, 1986, defendant
21
UPCHURCH approved five deiys solitary confinement for plaintiff
22
JOHNSON.
23
72.  On August 9, 1986, after plaintiff JOHNSON had been in
24
solitary confinement for five days, defendant UPCHURCH ordered
25
that he remain in Yucca Cottage in punitive segregation
26
indefinitely on "motivational hold."  Under this program,
27
plaintiff JOHNSON could be released from Yucca Cottage only at the
28
17

discretion  of defendant UPCHURCH.  Defendant UPCHURCH  kept
plaintiff JOHNSON  in punitive segregation on "motivational  hold'
2
in Yucca Cottage  for a period  in excess of  50 days.
73.  Defendant UPCHURCH did not provide plaintiff  JOHNSON
4
with notice of an offense or violation of an institutional  rule
before placing him  in punitive segregation  or provide him with a
6
hearing.  Nor did defendant UPCHURCH advise plaintiff JOHNSON  when
he would be released  from punitive segregation or what he  was
8
required to do to be released  from punitive  segregation.
74.  Defendant UPCHURCH subjected plaintiff JOHNSON  to
10
unnecessarily harsh and cruel practices, conditions, and
11
punishments while  in punitive segregation.  Defendant  UPCHURCH
12
permitted plaintiff JOHNSON to leave his cell to shower, brush  his
13
teeth, and comb his hair only every other day; he restricted  his
14
visits with his father to one-half hour on Saturdays and Sundays;
15
he did not permit him to receive telephone  calls from his  father;
16
and he did not permit him to make telephone  calls to his  father.
17
75.  Defendant UPCHURCH  failed to provide plaintiff  JOHNSON
18
with any educational program while he was  in punitive  segregation
19
and defendant UPCHURCH prohibited plaintiff JOHNSON  from  taking
20
his Graduate Equivalency Examination  (GED) while he was  in
21
punitive  segregation.
22
76.  Defendant UPCHURCH directed that plaintiff  JOHNSON'S
23
legal papers be confiscated,  read, and  withheld.
24
C  FACTS IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFF M.G.'S  CLAIMS FOR DAMAGES,
25
AGAINST DEFENDANTS HURTT AND  KORFF
26
77.  M.G. was  first committed  to the custody of the  ADOC
27
for probation violation, running away, and  indecent exposure  on
28
18

f f
September 24, 1986 when he was 14 years old.
1
78.  While M.G. was under the care, custody, and control of
2
the ADOC, he was confined at AMJI from September 26, 1986 to
3
October 29, 1986; at CMJI from October 29, 1986 to February 12,
4
1987; at CMJI from March 25, 1987 to August 8, 1987; at CMJI from
5
September 4, 1987 to December 9, 1987; at AMJI from December  9,
6
1987 to May 18, 1987; at CMJI from May 18, 1988 to June 7, 1988;
7
at Sonora Desert Hospital from June 7, 1988 to June 17, 1988; at
8
Arizona State Hospital from June 17, 1988 to July 8, 1988; at CMJI
9
from September 2, 1988 to March 2, 1989; at Jane Wayland
10
Residential Treatment Center from July 17, 1989 to August 28,
11
1989; at CMJI from August 28, 1989 to August 30, 1989; and at
12
Alamo Juvenile Institution  from August 30, 1989 to December 22,
13
1989.
14
79.  At the time M.G. was first committed to the custody of
15
the ADOC, Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT knew or should have known
16
that M.G. was seriously emotionally handicapped and  learning
17
disabled. Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT failed to establish
18
policies, procedures and regulations within the ADOC to insure
19
that M.G. was properly evaluated and to insure that a treatment
20
plan was prepared and implemented which addressed his treatment
21
needs. Instead, Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT approved the transfer
22
of M.G. to CMJI which she knew or should have known was unable to
23
adequately meet his treatment and educational needs.
24
80.  Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT knowingly and  deliberately
25
failed to develop and implement regulations, rules, and policies
26
of the ADOC so as to insure that M.G. received treatment and
27
education appropriate to his needs. Defendant CAROL MOORE HURT
28
19

f  f.
knowingly and deliberately failed to employ, train, and supervise
staff to identify and address M.G.'s treatment and educational
needs.
81.  Defendant CAROL MOORE HURTT knowingly and deliberately
4
failed to provide academic and special education programs for M.G.
which meet the reguirements of state and federal law.
82.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendant CAROL
MOORE HURTT's failure to address M.G.'s treatment and educational
needs within the ADOC, or to place M.G. in an alternate program or
10 setting which could identify and address his treatment and
educational needs, M. G.'s condition progressively deteriorated
11
while he was in the custody of ADOC.
12
83.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendant THOMAS
13
KORFF's failure to develop and implement institutional policies,
14
rules, and regulations and as a direct and proximate result of
15
Defendant KORFF's failure to employ, train, and supervise staff to
16
provide care and supervision for M.G., CMJI staff under the direct
17
supervision and control of Defendant KORFF, and with his knowledge
18
and consent, repeatedly subjected M.G. to arbitrary and cruel
19
punishments, including placing him in handcuffs, belly-chains, and
20
four-point restraints and confining him in solitary confinement
21
for extended periods of time, as punishment for behavior which was
22
the result of his handicapping conditions.
23
84.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendant THOMAS
24
KORFF's failure to address M.G.'s treatment and educational needs
25
while at CMJI, M. G.'s condition progressively deteriorated while
26
he was at CMJI.
27
85.  Defendant THOMAS KORFF knowingly and deliberately
28
20

f
  r
failed to provide academic and special education programs for M.G.
which meet the requirements of state and federal law.
8 6.  At the direction of Defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and
THOMAS KORFF, CMJI staff repeatedly subjected M.G. to cruel and
4
arbitrary punishments, including confining him in solitary
confinement for extended periods and placing him in handcuffs,
6
belly chains, and four-point restraints, as punishment for
behavior which was the result of his handicapping conditions.
8
87.  In addition to failing to provide appropriate
treatment for M.G. while he was in their care and custody,
10
defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and THOMAS KORFF obstructed efforts
11
to identify M.G.'s treatment needs by others acting on his behalf.
12
For example, defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and THOMAS KORFF
13
attempted to prevent plaintiffs' expert consultant from evaluating
14
M.G. which resulted in delays in responding to M.G.'s treatment
15
needs.
16
88. Defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and THOMAS KORFF knowingly
17
and deliberately failed to develop and implement an appropriate
18
release plan for M.G. Although they knew or should have known that
19
M.G. did not possess the social, academic, or vocational skills
20
necessary to function successfully in a non-institutional setting
21
and although they knew or should have known that M.G.'s home was
22
an inappropriate placement, defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and
23
THOMAS KORFF nevertheless released M.G. on his eighteenth birthday
24
without transition funds or services.
25
89.  Defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and THOMAS  KORFF
26
knowingly and deliberately  failed to employ, train, and  supervise
27
adequate staff at CMJI to protect M.G. from harm.
28
21

r
90.  Defendants CAROL MOORE HURTT and THOMAS KORFF
knowingly and deliberately failed to establish parole services
which are adequate to protect the rights of M.G. Defendants CAROL
MOORE HURTT and KORFF subjected M.G. to parole revocation
procedures which they knew or should have known were violative of
his rights.
LEGAL CLAIMS
7
First Claim
8
91.  Defendants' use of solitary confinement, punitive
segregation, handcuffs, and shackles as described herein violates
10
plaintiffs' rights guaranteed by the Eighth and Fourteenth
11
Amendments to the United States Constitution and Article 2,
12
Section 15 of the Constitution of the State of Arizona.
13
Second Claim
14
92.  Defendants' faiilure to provide adequate procedural
15
protections prior to the infliction of harsh and cruel punishments
16
as described herein, defendants' failure to protect plaintiffs
17
from harm while in state custody, and defendants' failure to
18
provide adequate and appropriate medical care, educational
19
programs, rehabilitative treatment, classification, evaluation,
20
and placement as described herein, violate plaintiffs' rights
21
guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States
22
Constitution and Article 2, Section 4 of the Constitution of the
23
State of Arizona.
24
Third Claim
25
93.  Defendants' interference with plaintiffs' access to
26
counsel, the courts, and their families as described herein
27
violates plaintiffs' rights guaranteed by the First and Sixth
28
22

Amendments to the United States Constitution and Article 2,
1
Section  6 of the Constitution of the State of Arizona.
2
Fourth  Claim
3
94.  Defendants' failure to properly  evaluate  plaintiffs
4
for handicapping  conditions and to provide special  education
5
services as described herein, violates plaintiffs' rights
6
guaranteed by the Education  for the Handicapped Act, 20 U.S.C.
7
Section  1401, et seq.
8
Fifth  Claim
9
95.  Defendants' failure to establish procedures  which
10
adequately protect the rights of plaintiffs during parole
11
revocation proceedings violates plaintiffs' rights guaranteed  by
12
the Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitutions.
13
NO ADEQUATE REMEDY AT LAW
14
95.  AS a proximate result of the defendants' policies,
15
practices, acts and omissions complained  of herein, and the
16
conditions and circumstances described above to which  plaintiffs
17
are subjected, plaintiffs have suffered, do suffer, and will
18
continue to suffer immediate and irreparable  injury.  Plaintiffs
19
have no plain, adequate, or complete remedy at law to redress the
20
wrongs described herein.  Plaintiffs will continue to be
21
irreparably  injured by the policies, practices, acts and  omissions
22
of defendants unless this Court grants the injunctive relief which
23
plaintiffs  seek.
24
PRAYER FOR RELIEF
25
WHEREFORE, plaintiffs, on their own behalf and on behalf of
26
all others similarly situated, pray that this Court;
27
A.  Assume jurisdiction  of this action;
28
23

r
B.  Award damages against defendant JAMES UPCHURCH  in his
personal  capacity  to plaintiff MATTHEW  DAVEY JOHNSON  in an  amount
which the Court deems  proper;
3
C.  Award damages against defendants  CAROL MOORE HURTT  and
4
THOMAS KORFF  in their personal capacities to plaintiff M.G.  in an
5
amount which the Court deems proper;
6
D.  Issue a judgment pursuant to 2 8 U.S.C. Section 2 2 01
7
and 2202 and Rule 57 of the Federal Rules of Civil  Procedure
8
declaring  that by subjecting plaintiffs to the conditions  of
9
confinement described herein defendants THOMAS KORFF, CAROL MOORE,
10
and SAMUEL LEWIS have violated plaintiffs' rights guaranteed  by
11
the First, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the  United
12
States Constitution, the Arizona Constitution, the Education  for
13
the Handicapped Act, 20 U.S.C. Section 1401 et seq.,  the
14
regulations promulgated  thereunder, and Arizona  statutes  and
15
regulations.
16
E.  Issue a judgment pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Section  2201
17
and  2202 and Rule 57 of the Federal Rules of Civil  Procedure
18
declaring  that by subjecting plaintiffs to the conditions  and
19
practices described  herein at paragraphs  53-58, defendant  BISHOP
20
has violated plaintiffs' rights guaranteed  by the Education  for
21
the Handicapped  Act, 20 U.S.C. Section 1401 et seq.,  regulations
22
promulgated  thereunder, and Arizona  statutes and  regulations.
23
F.  Issue preliminary  and permanent  injunctions  enjoining
24
the defendants THOMAS KORFF, CAROL MOORE, and SAMUEL LEWIS,  their
25
agents, employees, successors  in office and  assigns  from  engaging
26
in unconstitutional  and unlawful  acts and practices  including,  but
27
not limited to:
28
24

f  f
1)  Subjecting plaintiffs to solitary confinement,
punitive segregation, handcuffs and shackles as punishment for
violations of institutional rules;
2)  Failing to provide appropriate procedural
4
safeguards prior to punishing plaintiffs;
3)  Confining plaintiffs in unsafe, unsanitary and
6
unhealthy facilities;
4)  Interfering with plaintiffs' right of access to
8
counsel, the courts and their families;
5)  Failing to provide plaintiffs with appropriate
10
medical, dental, and psychiatric care;
11
6)  Failing to adequately screen and evaluate
12
plaintiffs to ensure that they are not inappropriately confined at
13
CMJI;
14
7)  Failing to provide sufficient staff with
15
appropriate training, experience and supervision to insure
16
plaintiffs' safety and to provide plaintiffs with  rehabilitative
17
treatment.
18
G.  Issue preliminary and permanent injunctions enjoining
19
the defendants THOMAS KORFF, CAROL MOORE, SAMUEL LEWIS, C. DIANE
20
BISHOP, and the ARIZONA BOARD OF EDUCATION, their agents,
21
employees, successors in office and assigns from failing to
22
provide plaintiffs with appropriate and necessary  educational
23
services, including special education and related services, in a
24
manner that does not comply with the requirements of federal and
25
state statutes and regulations.
26
H.  Retain jurisdiction over defendants THOMAS KORFF,
27
CAROL MOORE, SAMUEL LEWIS, C. DIANE BISHOP, and the ARIZONA BOARD
28
25

f  (
,  OF EDUCATION and each of them until such time as the Court is
โ  satisfied that their unlawful policies, practices, acts, and
โ  omissions complained of herein no longer exist and will not recur.
.  I.  Award plaintiffs the costs of this proceeding,
attorneys' fees under 42 U.S.C. Section 1988, and such other and
further relief as to this Court seems just and proper.
6

16

17
gram.  He  alleged  that  he  was  being  held  in  Yucca  Cottage  arbitrarily,  in

19 violation of his constitutionail  rights.

III. Limitations on Institutional  Populations
9
1.  Least Restrictive  Environment
10
11 A.  The principle which shall guide the Department in its decisions regarding
12 out-of-home  placement  of  delinquent  youth  is  that  every  youth
13
committed  to  the  custody  of  the  Department  has  a  right  to  receive
14
individualized care and treatment in the least restrictive setting consistent
15
with the youth's needs and the protection of the public.  The presumption
16
shall be that each youth's best interests are served by remaining in his or
17
18 her home community  with  necessary  services  provided  there, provided
19 that the youth poses no undue risk to the community.  The Department
20
shall continue its efforts  to develop and implement  a plan to work with
21
committing  courts to increase  community  based  services  for youth not
22
appropriate  for secure care.
23
(1)  The Department shall conduct a diagnostic review for each youth

youth into secure  care after  diagnostic  review except  youth who

2 pose a threat  to public safety,  or who have engaged  in a pattern
3
of  conduct  characterized  by  persistent  and  delinquent  offenses
4
that, as demonstrated  through the use of other alternatives, cannot
5  I
be  controlled  in  a  less  secure  settings  or  who  have  had  their
6
conditional  liberty  revoked  pursuant  to  the  Arizona  Revised
7

10
classification  or risk assessment  instrument as the basis for deter-
11
mining the appropriate  level of restrictiveness.

X.  Orientation/Youth  Handbook
14
15 1.  The  Department  shall  provide  each  committed  youth  with  a copy  of a youth
16 handbook.  The purpose of this handbook  is to advise youth of their rights and
17
inform  them  about the institutional  program,  applicable  rules  of conduct,  and
18
potential  sanctions  for  violations  of  rules.  The  Department  shall  make  the
19
handbook  available in Spanish.
20
2.  The Department  shall  also provide an orientation  for  every  committed  youth.
21
22 The  orientation  shall  include  information  on  the  rights  of  youth  in  the
23
institutional  program, responsibilities  of youth in secure confinement,  rules of
24
conduct,  and potential  sanctions.
25
26
17
AO 72
(Rev 8/82)

XI.  Staff
1.  The Department  shall employ qualified  casework,  recreation,  direct child-care,
1
j
23 j and other staff  in sufficient  numbers and with sufficient  training.
i
2.  A sufficient  number of direct child-care  workers means not less than  1 worker
4 !! to 8 youth during the afternoon  shift,  and not less than  1 worker to 16 youth
5
during normal sleeping hours.
6
3.  Qualifications  for direct-care  staff  shall include, at a minimum,  six months of
7
experience working with youth in organized activities or programs.  Successful
8
completion  of fifteen  (15) semester  hours  of studies  in social  or  behavioral
9
10 sciences  applicable  to  a  bachelors  degree  may  substitute  for  the  required
11
experience.
12 '!'!
4.  The  Department  shall  provide  adequate  training  appropriate  to  the  job
13
assignment  for administrative  staff,  youth  caseworkers,  specialist  employees,
14
support staff, and part-time  staff.
15
XII.  Protection  from Arbitrary  Punishments
16
17 1.  Exclusion
18
A.  Exclusion  is removal  of a youth  from  regular programming  or contact
19
with other youth by confinement  in a locked room, except during normal
20
sleeping  hours.  The room may or may not be the youth's  own room.
21
Exclusion  may  be  used  only  for  a  "cooling  off  period,  not  for
22
punishment  or the convenience  of staff,  and shall  not exceed  2 hours.
23
24 Staff shall explain the reasons for exclusion and provide an opportunity
25
26
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

for the youth  to explain  his/her  behavior.  The Department's  goal  is to
1 limit the use of exclusion and, when youth must be excluded, to limit the
2 time  in exclusion.  Staff  shall  interact  with  youth  in exclusion  at least
3
every  30 minutes  to attempt  to return the youth  to the regular  cottage
4
program.
5
2.  Separation
6
A.  Separation is confinement  in a designated security unit to segregate youth
7
8 from  the  general  population.  Separation  is  a  serious  and  extreme
9 measure  which  staff  shall  not  impose  unless  necessary  to protect  the
10
youth or others from  imminent risk of injury,  to prevent  imminent  and
11
substantial  destruction  of property,  to prevent  imminent  and substantial
12
disruption  of  the  facility,  or  where  there  are  reasonable  grounds  to
13
believe that a youth is a serious and continuing  escape  risk.  It may not
14
be imposed as punishment for infractions of institutional  rules, or for the
15
16 convenience  of  staff.  The  Department  may  separate  a  youth  who
17
requests  separation  and  does not meet  these  criteria,  but  must  release
18
such youth upon request unless they meet these criteria.  [Note:  Medical
19
isolation is not separation and is not governed  by this section.]
20
B.  The Department shall designate Crisis Management  Teams composed  of
21
22 staff specially trained in crisis intervention techniques.  These teams shall
23 attempt to avoid the use of separation  by mediating  conflicts  involving
24
youth.  If less restrictive  efforts  to resolve conflicts  are unsuccessful  or
25
26
19
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

impractical, the Crisis Management Team may escort youth to separation.
Youth may be admitted to separation with the approval of the responsible
1
2 supervisor  or responsible  caseworker  present  at the youth's  institution.
3
Staff shall not routinely apply restraint devices to youth while escorting
4
them to separation.
5  J
C.  When a youth  is admitted  to a separation  unit, staff  shall  immediately
6
develop  an  action  plan  to  resolve  the  conflict  so that  the  youth  may
7
return  to  the  cottage  program.  The  action  plan  shall  include  release
8
9 criteria.  The action plan shall also identify  the behaviors which must be
10
addressed  for the youth to be released  from  separation  and the way in
11
which  the Department  will  encourage  these  behaviors,  including  goals
12
and timetables leading to release.  Staff shall release youth from separa-
13
tion  when they  have  met the  release  criteria  as outlined  in the  action
14
plan,  and shall  not  impose  by policy  or practice  minimum  periods  of
15
16 time  in  separation  for  designated  behaviors  or  offenses.  Stable,
17
cooperative behavior and meeting the release criteria indicate that separa-
18
tion is unnecessary.
19
D.  The Department shall not confine any youth in separation for longer than
20
24  hours  without  providing  a  hearing  within  24  hours  to  determine
21
whether continued  separation  is necessary to protect the youth or others
22
23 from  imminent  risk  of  injury,  to  prevent  imminent  and  substantial
24 property damage, to prevent substantial disruption of the facility, or there
25
26
20
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

are  reasonable  grounds  to  believe  that  the  youth  is  a  serious  and
continuing escape risk.  In making that determination,  the hearing  officer
1
2 shall review the action plan for reasonableness  and the youth's  progress
3
toward meeting the release criteria.  The Department  shall provide youth
4
with  written  and  verbal  notification  of its reasons  for  continued  sepa-
5
ration,  and  shall  make  available  an  advocate  to  assist  the  youth  in
6
presenting  information  at the hearing.  The youth has a right to contact
7
a parent  or  guardian,  to speak  on his own  behalf  or  remain  silent,  to
8
9 present evidence, and to question  witnesses.  The Department  shall not
10
confine  a youth  in separation  longer than 24 hours unless an  impartial
11
hearing  officer  makes  written  findings  supporting  specific  separation
12
criteria  based  upon  information  presented  at the hearing.  The  Depart-
13
ment shall provide an opportunity  for prompt review of the decision of
14
the hearing officer  and shall provide the youth with written  notification
15
16 of the outcome of the review and the reasons.
17
The youth's  caseworker  shall review the action plans, and the  youth's
18
progress towards release, at least daily for  all youth held in separation
19
longer than 48 hours.  The Deputy  Director  or designee  must  approve
20
continued confinement  of a youth daily after the fifth day.  The Director,
21
or  in  the  Director's  absence,  the  Deputy  Director,  must  approve
22
23 continued  confinement  daily after the tenth day.
24
The  size,  furnishings,  lighting,  heat  and  ventilation  of  the  separation
25
26
21
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

rooms  shall  approximate  the  conditions  in  the  regular  living  cottages.
Absent  a documented  need  to remove  an  item  to protect  a youth,  the
1
2 Department  shall  provide  youth  in  separation  with  a  bed,  mattress,
3
pillow,  sheets,  blankets,  regular  clothing,  and  reading  materials.  The
4
Department  shall also allow a youth  in separation  to send  and  receive
5
mail, to visit with parents, guardians and attorneys, and to participate in
6
educational  and  recreational  programs,  except  in  those  unusual
7
circumstances  when doing so would jeopardize  safety and security.
8
9 G.  The Department  shall maintain  a log which  records  the name of every
youth  confined  in  separation,  the  date  and  time  of  confinement,  the
11  ii
reasons  for confinement,  including  specific  descriptions  of the  youth's
12 i!
behavior,  the name of the individual  who has approved  separation,  and
13
the date and time of release.  The signatures  of the persons  who  have
14
15 approved separation and its extension shall be maintained  in the youth's
16 security  file.
17
3. Mechanical  Restraints
18
A.  The use of restraint devices is an extreme and exceptional measure which
19
shall  be  used  only  when  a  youth  is  out  of  control  and  other  less
20
restrictive means to bring the youth under control have failed.  Members
21
22 of the Crisis Management  Team or other staff who are specially  trained
23 in the  use  of restraint  devices  and  crisis  intervention  techniques  may
24
restrain a youth to protect the youth or others from imminent harm or to
25
26
22
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

L
prevent  substantial  property  damage.  Staff  shall  remove  the  restraint
devices when they are no longer necessary  to protect the youth or others
1
2 from  imminent harm or to prevent substantial  property damage.
3
B.  Staff must continuously observe youth in restraint devices and a licensed
4
medical  staff  person must check  the youth  immediately  after  restraints
5  |
are  applied  and  at  least  every  30  minutes  thereafter.  A  licensed
ยซ!
ii
psychologist  must authorize  the use of restraints after  two hours, and a
7 I!
psychiatrist  must  authorize  the  use  of continued  restraints  after  three
9 hours.
10
C.  Youth shall not be restrained to each other or to fixed objects, except that
11
a youth's  arms  and  legs  may  be secured  to a bed  frame  with  soft  re-
12
straints  if  authorized  by  the  psychologist  or  on-call  Central  Office
13
Administrator.  Staff  may  contact  the  psychologist  or  on-call  Central
14
15 Office  Administrator  for  authorization  immediately  subsequent  to
16 restraining  the youth,  if the youth's  behavior  actively  poses  immediate
17
physical harm to self or others.
18
D.  The Department shall maintain a log containing the names of each youth
19
placed in restraint devices, the time the youth was restrained, the time the
20
restraints were removed, a description of the events leading to the use of
21
22 restraints,  and the name of the individual  who has approved  restraints.
23
The signatures of the persons approving the use of mechanical  restraints
24
and its extension  shall be maintained  in the youth's security  file.
25
26
23
AO 72
(Rev 8/82)

E.  The Department  shall not routinely  restrain youth during  transportation
to or from secure facilities, but may restrain youth during  transportation
1
2 when  staff  have  reasonable  grounds  to  believe  that  use  of  restraint
3
devices is necessary  to protect the safety of the youth or others.  Youth
4
restrained during transportation may not be restrained to one another, but
5
are not subject to the other provisions of subsections  A, B, C and D of
6
this section.
7
8 XIII.  Parole Revocation
9 When the Department  believes that a youth has violated  a term of conditional
10
liberty, it may initiate revocation proceedings pursuant to A.R.S. ยง41-2819.  The
11
Department may take a youth into custody pursuant to A.R.S. ยง41-2819 or may
12
serve  the  youth  with  a citation  to  appear  at a probable  cause  hearing.  The
13
Department  shall  inform  any  youth  served  with  a  warrant  or  citation  of  the
14
reasons  for the initiation  of the revocation  proceedings  and the youth's  rights
15
16 related to the proceedings.
17
Within 72 hours of a youth's  return to a secure  facility,  the Department  shall
18
provide  or ensure  a hearing  to determine  whether  there  is probable  cause  to
19
believe that the youth has violated a term of conditional liberty and whether or
20
not  the  youth  shall  remain  in  a  secure  facility  to  assure  attendance  at  a
21
revocation  hearing and/or for community  safety, or the safety  of the youth.
22
23 The Department  shall provide or ensure a hearing for youth within  10 business
24
days of detention  to determine  whether conditional  liberty should  be revoked.
25
26
24
AO 72
(Rev .8/82)

The  Department  shall  provide  specially  trained,  impartial  hearing  examiners,
1 acting  under  the direct  supervision  of an attorney,  to hear  parole  revocations.
2 The Department  shall make available  an attorney, or an advocate  acting  under
3
the  direct  supervision  of  an  attorney,  to  assist  youth  at  parole  revocation
4
hearings.  Hearing examiners and advocates shall not be supervised  by the same
5
attorney.  Youth shall have a right to written notice of the charges,  to remain
6
silent,  to  call  witnesses,  and  to  question  adverse  witnesses.  The  hearing
7
8 examiner  shall make written findings of fact.
9 XIV.  Implementation  and Monitoring
10
1.  The Department  shall prepare a plan or plans within 90 days to implement  this
11  i
Consent Decree.  The implementation  plan(s) shall include a description  of the
12
tasks to be accomplished, personnel (individuals or job titles) responsible for the
13
tasks, and timetables  for completion  of the tasks.
14
15 2.  A Committee  of Consultants  (Committee)  composed  of one person  designated
16
by  the  plaintiffs,  one  person  designated  by the  Department,  and  one  person
17
jointly  designated  by the  parties  whose  designation  will  be  subject  to  Court
18
approval, shall review the adequacy of the plan(s) implementing  all sections  of
19
this Consent Decree and shall monitor for the Department's compliance with the
20
plan(s).  The Committee shall also consult with the Department as requested and
21
22 mediate disputes between  the parties concerning  compliance.  The Department
23
anticipates  a cooperative  relationship  with the Committee.
24
3.  The Committee shall inspect each of the Department's secure institutions at least
25
26
25
AO 72
(Rev .8/82)

every  six  months,  but  may  inspect  more  often  with  the  agreement  of  the
Director, which shall not be unreasonably  withheld, or to observe Departmental
1
2 i; action in response to problems identified  and acknowledged  as problems by the
3 |
Director.  The Committee need not inspect every 6 months if the Committee and
4  ii
the parties agree that such inspections  are not necessary.
5
The Committee  shall  issue  a written  report  within  30 days  of any  inspection
6
describing the Department's progress in achieving compliance with this Consent
7
Decree and its implementation  plans.  The Committee shall provide copies of its
8
9 report to the Court and the parties.  Any party may respond to any report filed
10
by the Committee.
11  II
Either party may raise questions  of compliance  with this Consent  Decree with
12  j|
any member of the Committee  and the Committee  shall attempt to resolve the
13
questions  informally.  If  the  Committee  is  unable  to  resolve  the  questions
14
15 informally,  either  party may request that the Committee  make formal  findings
16 of fact.  Either party  may respond  to the Committee's  findings  of  fact.  The
17
findings of the Committee  shall  be final and binding  unless  either  party  files
18
objections  with the Court within 30 days.  The Court shall hear the matter de
19
novo and the burden of persuasion  shall be on the party filing the objections.
20
The Departments  shall provide  copies of any existing  documents  or access  to
21
records, files and reports maintained  by the Departments  concerning  youth that
22
23 the  Committee  considers  necessary  to  evaluate  compliance.  Members  of  the
24
Committee may discuss matters related to this Consent Decree with any youth
25
26
26
AO 72
(Rev.8/82)

confined  by the Department  or any employee.  The Departments  may designate
liaisons  to respond  to the  requests  of the Committee.  The  State  of  Arizona,
acting  on  behalf  of  the  Departments,  shall  be  responsible  for  the  reasonable
expenses  of the members of the Committee.
XV.  Dismissal
1.  This Consent  Decree shall take effect  on the date of its approval  by the Court,
pursuant  to Rule 23, Fed. R. Civ. Pro., and shall  remain  in effect  for  4 years
i!
from  that date.  This case shall be dismissed  with prejudice  4 years  from  that
9 date unless the parties agree to an extension or the plaintiffs  object to dismissal
10
and the Court orders an extension.  In the event the plaintiffs  object to dismissal,
11  !
they shall designate  the paragraph(s)  of this Consent  Decree  they contend  the
12
Department  has  breached.  The  parties  shall  exhaust  the  informal  dispute
13
resolution  mechanisms  described  in paragraph  XIV(6)  above  before  plaintiffs
14
move the Court  for an extension,  and the date of dismissal  shall  be extended
15
16 while such informal dispute resolution mechanisms are pending.  The Court shall
17 extend  this  Consent  Decree  only  as  to the  paragraph(s)  for  which  the  Court
18
determines  that the Departments  are not in compliance.
19
20 Dated:  This day of
21
22
23
Richard  M. Bilby
24
United States District  Judge
25
26
27
AO 72
(Rev 8/82)

Approved:
1
2
3
David  Lambert Louis !A. Goodr
National  Center  for Youth Law Ronald A. Lebowitz, P. C.
4
Counsel  for  Plaintiffs Counsel  for  Defendants
5
6
7
TO
8 Grace  Mcllvain Ronald A.
Miller, Pitt & McAnally,  P.C. Ronald  A. Lebowitz,

Counsel  for  Plaintiffs Counsel  for  Defendants

documents.title: Order re: Consent Decree Population Limitations
documents.text:
Johnson v. Upchurch
APR  1
n
1
JI-AZ-002-003  ^:J^V-'1-
2 IN THE  UNITED  STATES DISTRICT  COUKJ
3 FOR THE DISTRICT  OF  ARIZONA
4
5
MATTHEW DAVEY JOHNSON,  et al., NO. CIV 86-195 TUC  RMB
6
Plaintiff,
7
vs.
8
JAMES R. UPCHURCH,  et al.,
9
Defendants.
10
11
12
ORDER RE: CONSENT DECREE POPULATION  LIMITATIONS
13
14
On May 6,1993, the Court approved a Consent Decree which placed population
15
limitations on the number of youths who could be confined at the Arizona Department
16
of  Juvenile  Corrections  ("ADJC").  Specifically,  the  Consent  Decree  provided  in
17
relevant part:
18
The  Department  shall not  average  more than  110 youth  at CMS  each
19 month,  240  youth  at  AMS  each  month,  and  30  youth  in  the  BCS
residential program each month, unless additional physical facilities  are
20 constructed to house such youtns  in accordance with the standards set
forth  in paragraph 2{B).
21
See Consent Decree, IIL2.A. at 7.  The Decree further  requires that ADJC obtain  the
22
consent of the Committee of Consultants before increasing the total number of secure
23
beds.  Id., III.2.C. at 8.
24
At no time has ADJC been in compliance with the Consent Decree population
25
limitations.
26
Subsequent to the Decree, A.R.S. ยง 8-241 was enacted.  That statute confers upon
the juvenile courts the authority to not only commit youth to the Department, but to
โข\

also designate minimum lengths of stay in secure confinement.  A.R.S. ยง 8-241 in effect,
eliminates the discretion previously held by the Department to regulate its population.
To  address  an  increasing  population,  ADJC  sought  the  approval  of  the
Committee  of  Consultants  and  the  Court  to  increase  the  number  of  its  secure
residential beds.  Based on the recommendations from the Committee of Consultants,
the Court  authorized  increasing the capacity of AMS from  240 to 312 beds and BCS
7  from 30 residential beds to 120 beds.  See Order of November 27, 1995.  Approval was
also given for new construction: a 24-bed boot camp and two 24-bed cottages, subject
to  design  approval  and  meeting  Consent  Decree  standards.  Id.  That  Order
10  immediately  increased  the  bed  capacity  at  the  three  institutions  to  542  with  an
11  additional 72 beds made available upon completion.  Despite this increased  capacity,
12  demographic factors and significant changes in Arizona law have prevented ADJC from
13  satisfying  the population limits.
14  The Committee of Consultants submitted their Fifth Semi-Annual Report on the
15  Implementation  of  the  Consent  Decree  (the  "Report")  on January  30,  1996.  The
16  Report  found  that  ADJC  was violating  the population  limits  by  51 youths.  The
17  Report  recommended  that  ADJC  be  held  accountable  to  the  Consent  Decree
18  population  provisions.
19  At hearing held February 9. 1996, ADJC assured the Court that by applying a
20  variety  of program  options, it would  be at, or under, the population  caps within 60
21  days.  Based on those assurances, the Court  ordered:
22  that  Director  Eugene Moore  and the Arizona  Department  of Juvenile
Corrections shall be in compliance with the Consent Decree on or before
23  5:00 P.M., APRIL 9, 1996.  Director Moore shall submit  a compliance
report  to the Court  If this report does not satisfy  the Court,  the
24  Court shall issue an Order at 5:01 PJvl., April 9, 1996 which will ensure
DJC complies with the terms of the Consent Decree.
25
See Order of February 21, 1996.
26
The  Department  asserts  today  that  it  made  its  assurances  to  the  Court  on
27
28

February 9, 1996 based on juvenile court commitment  practices during the period of
October 1995 through December 1995. Unanticipated at the time, was.that the number
of  youth  committed  to  ADJC  with  determinate  lengths  of  stay  would  increase  by
14.5%.  According to ADJC, despite the Administrative Office of the Courts' promise
that  the juvenile courts would endeavor to limit commitments  to those youths  who
satisfy  the commitment  guidelines, this has not occurred.  Instead, since February 9,
1996, the  secure  care population  has exceeded  the requirements  set by the  Consent
Decree  by an average of 78 youths.  As of April 9, 1996, ADJC's secure  population
exceeded the capacity by 72 youth.
10  As required by the Court's February 9, 1996 Order, Defendants submitted  on
11  March  20,  1996 their  Plan  for  Complying with  the population  requirements  of  the
12  Decree.  After reviewing the Plan, the Court finds: (1) the Plan gives no estimate as to
13  the projected  population  reductions which  would  occur  as a result  of the  proposed
14  programs;  (2) the overcrowding has actually increased since the Court's February  9,
15  1996 Order; and (3) Defendants' proposal that the capacity of Adobe Mountain School
16  be  temporarily  increased  until  the  new  construction  at  Black  Canyon  School  is
17  completed  is  contrary  to  Decree  requirements.  Accordingly,  the  Court  rejects
18  Defendants'  Plan as inadequate and in violation of Decree requirements.
19  This dilemma is the direct result of the Department's ongoing failure to provide
20  adequate physical facilities and personnel to staff those facilities.  The juvenile judges
21  of this State have been forced into an untenable position:  Do they commit youths to
22  overcrowded  state institutions, keep them in overcrowded  local institutions  (if such
23  even exists), or release them back to the community?  This was to be solved by the
24  State when it agreed to the Consent Decree.  The State has defaulted on its agreement
25  and this Court has no recourse but to force Defendants  to live up to their agreement.
26
27
28
โขT

1  Having  considered  these  issues,  relevant  documents,  ADJC  March  20,  1996
2  Population  Plan,  the Committee  of  Consultants'  recommendations,  and good  cause
3  appearing  therefor,
4  IT IS ORDERED  that:
5  (1)  The  Arizona  Department  of  Juvenile  Corrections  is  in  violation  of
6  Paragraph  III.2.A. of the Consent Decree;
7  (2)  ADJC  is hereby  enjoined  as of  this date  from  accepting  any youth  in
8  excess of 110 at Catalina Mountain School; 312 at Adobe Mountain School and 120 at
9  Black Canyon School;
10  (3)  Those youth  received by the Department  must meet one of the criteria
11  set forth  in the Consent Decree at Section III.l.A.(l).
12  (4)  Each youth in the custody of ADJC shall be provided equal access to the
13  full continuum  of services offered  by ADJC as prescribed  by Section IV.2.D. of  the
14  Consent Decree;
15  (5)  Nothing herein alters or amends this Court's November 27, 1996 Order
16  provided that the yet-to-be-constructed two 24-beds units and the 24-boot camp comply
17  with the full continuum of services;
18  (6)  In the event that there is limited bed space for committed youth waiting
19  transportation to the physical custody of ADJC, it shall contact the respective juvenile
20  courts to give the committing courts the opportunity to meet and confer in order to
21  designate which committed youth shall be placed in ADJC's secure care.  In the event
22  that the committing courts cannot agree among themselves within two working days,
23  the decision  of which youth shall be placed in ADJC custody shall be made by the
24  Chief Justice of the Arizona Supreme Court or his designee;
25  (7)  No youth for whom a revocation proceeding pursuant to A.R.S. ยง 41-2819
26  has been or will be instituted, shall be held in a secure facility operated by the ADJC
27
28  4

if such placement  will exceed the population provisions approved  by this  Court;
(8)  No youth who has been assigned to conditional liberty by ADJC who is
arrested for a new offense shall be placed in a secure facility operated by ADJC pending
a probable cause hearing;
(9)  If, following a probable cause hearing, it is determined to prosecute on the
new offense(s)  such youth  will not  be placed in a secure facility  operated  by  ADJC
7  prior to sentencing;
8  (10)  Nothing shall prohibit the Department from petitioning the Committee
of Consultants for additional beds in accordance with the Consent Decree;
10  (11)  ADJC shall continue to submit reports to the Committee of Consultants
11  in accordance with the Court's February 21, 1996 Order;
12  (12)  If ADJC is not in compliance with this Order by 5:00 P.M., May 9, 1996,
13  Defendants  shall be held in contempt of court.
14
